Chapter 1, Section 2: Analysis of the Elements. Furthermore, among the eighteen elements explained above, how many are visible and how many are invisible?
How many are resistant and how many are non-resistant?
How many are wholesome, how many are unwholesome, and how many are indeterminate?
Verse:
One is visible, namely form. Ten have form and are resistant.
Excluding form and sound, the other eight are indeterminate. The rest are of three kinds.
Discussion:
Among the eighteen elements, the form element is visible, because it can be indicated as having distinctions here and there.
By this meaning, the others are said to be invisible.
Thus, the visible and invisible have been explained.
Only the form aggregate, which includes ten elements, is resistant. Resistance means obstruction.
This is further of three kinds:
Because of the differences in obstruction, object, and support.
Obstruction as resistance refers to the ten elements with form.
It does not arise when it encounters resistance from another, as when hand encounters hand or stone encounters stone, or when two things resist each other.
The resistance of objects is that the twelve sense fields and part of the sense field of dharmas, which are all objects, are in objects such as form. Therefore the PrajÃ±aptiÅ›Ästra says:
There is an eye that is resistant in water but not on land, such as the eyes of fish, etc.
There is an eye that is resistant on land but not in water, which is said from the point of view of the majority of cases, such as the eyes of humans, etc.
There is an eye that is resistant in both, such as the eyes of piÅ›Äcas, Å›Ärmas, fishermen, frogs, etc.
There is an eye that is resistant in neither, which is the exception to the above.
There is an eye that is resistant at night but not in the daytime, such as the eyes of bats, owls, etc.
There is an eye that is resistant in the daytime but not at night, which is said from the point of view of the majority of cases, such as the eyes of humans, etc.
There is an eye that is resistant in both, such as the eyes of dogs, jackals, horses, leopards, wolves, cats, etc.
There is an eye that is resistant in neither, which is the exception to the above.
These are called objective obstruction.
Obstruction as object refers to mind and mental factors with regard to their own objects.
What is the difference between object and object as object?
If something has the power with regard to a dharma, it is said to be the object of that dharma.
Mind and mental factors grasp it and arise. It is called the object as object of mind, etc.
How is it said that when the eye, etc., revolve with regard to their own objects, they are called obstructed?
Because they do not revolve with regard to anything other than that.
Or, moreover, obstruction means the meaning of combination. It is said that because the dharmas of the eye, etc., revolve in combination with their own objects and their own objects as objects,

One should know that in this context, only with regard to obstruction as hindrance is it said, therefore it is only said that the ten with form have obstruction, because they mutually hinder each other.
Based on this meaning, the rest are said to be without obstruction.
If a dharma is obstructed as object, is it also obstructed as hindrance?
Four sentences should be made.
The seven mental elements and part of the element of dharmas, which are the associated dharmas, are the first sentence.
The five sense objects such as form are the second sentence.
The five sense faculties such as the eye are the third sentence.
Part of the element of dharmas, which are the non-associated dharmas, are the fourth sentence.
If a dharma is resistant in terms of object, is it also resistant in terms of object-support?
The subsequent sentence should be followed, which means that if it is resistant in terms of object-support, it must also be resistant in terms of object.
Although there are those that are resistant in terms of object, they are not resistant in terms of object-support, namely the five sense faculties such as the eye.
Here, the Venerable KumÄralÄta says this:
Where the mind wishes to arise, it is obstructed by others and does not arise.
One should know that this is resistance. Non-resistance is the opposite of this.
This is what is accepted.
Thus, resistance and non-resistance have been explained.

Among the ten that are resistant, the other eight are indeterminate, namely, the five material faculties, and the objects of smell, taste, and touch. They cannot be described as either good or bad, and therefore are called indeterminate.
Some say:
They are called indeterminate because they cannot be described as having retribution or not.
If this is so, then the pure should be only indeterminate.

The remaining ten elements are of three kinds, good, etc. The seven elements of consciousness are called good when they are associated with non-greed, etc.; they are called bad when they are associated with greed, etc.; the rest are called indeterminate.

The element of dharmas is called good when it is by nature non-greed, etc., or is associated with non-greed, etc., or is born together with non-greed, etc., or is cessation resulting from discrimination. It is called bad when it is by nature greed, etc., or is associated with greed, etc., or is born together with greed, etc. The rest is called indeterminate.
The elements of form and sound are called good or bad when they are bodily or vocal acts that are good or bad by the power of mind. The rest are indeterminate.
We have discussed the good, etc.
How many of the eighteen elements are bound to the realm of desire, how many are bound to the realm of form, and how many are bound to the formless realm?
A verse says:
In the desire realm, there are eighteen [types of consciousness], in the form realm, there are fourteen,
Excluding the two consciousnesses of smell and taste, in the formless realm, there are the last three.
The treatise says:
Bound means bound to, which is the meaning of being bound.

In the desire realm, there are eighteen [types of consciousness] in total. In the form realm, there are only fourteen types, excluding the objects of smell and taste, as well as the nose and tongue consciousnesses.
Excluding smell and taste is because they are of the nature of coarse food. One must be free from the desire for coarse food in order to be born there.
Excluding the nose and tongue consciousnesses is because there is no object [for them].

If that is so, then the element of touch should not exist there, because like the objects of smell and taste, it is of the nature of coarse food. The touch that exists there is not of the nature of coarse food.

If that is so, then smell and taste should also be the same. Apart from food, there is no separate enjoyment of smell and taste. Touch has a separate function of supporting the faculties, clothing, and so forth. Apart from the desire for food, smell and taste have no use, but because there are faculties, clothing, and so forth, touch is not non-existent.
Other masters say:

When one dwells in the formless realm and sees form and hears sound by means of the samÄdhi of the dhyÄnas, there is a special contact that arises together with pliancy and benefits the body. Therefore, these three are born in the dhyÄnas and still follow each other. Odor and taste are not like this, and therefore they do not exist there.
If this is so, then the nose and tongue must not exist there, because, like odor and taste, they are useless there.
The two organs have a use there, because one can speak and one can adorn the body.
If the use is to adorn the body and speak, then one needs only the two organs as bases. What use are the two organs?
Just as there is no organ of males, there is no organ as a base. If the two organs are absent, the base is also absent.
It is possible that the base of the male organ is absent there, because it is useless there.
The base of the nose and tongue is useful there, and therefore the organs must exist there, even apart from their objects.
Even though there is no use, the organs are born, just as in the womb of one who is to die.
Even though there is no use, there is no absence of a cause. From what cause can the arising of the organs be obtained?
When there is craving for the faculties, one generates superior karma.
If one is free from craving for objects, one would definitely be free from craving for the faculties. One who is free from craving for objects should not have a nose or tongue.
Or one should admit that the male organ would also arise. If one says it does not arise because it is ugly, how could the hidden penis be ugly?
Moreover, the arising of the faculties is not due to their function. If there is the power of a cause, they arise even without function.
Even though the male organ is ugly there, if it is admitted that there is a cause, it should arise there. If the male organ does not exist, the nose and tongue should also be absent.
If that is so, then it contradicts what is said in the sutra:
They are not lacking in limbs, and are not deficient in faculties.
It is said that they are not deficient in those faculties that should exist.
What is the contradiction?
If one does not admit this, the male organ should exist.

Those who say this say that the two faculties of nose and tongue do not exist there, but only smell and taste do not exist. Because craving for the six faculties arises based on the internal body, and cannot arise based on objects.

The love of the male organ arises from the contact of sexual desire. Sexual desire and the contact of sexual desire do not exist there, and therefore the male organ does not exist there. Therefore, in the realm of form, only fourteen kinds of elements are established.

The realm of desire has only the last three, namely, the mind, dharmas, and the mind consciousness element. One must be free from desire for form in order to be born there. Therefore, the ten elements of form do not exist in the formless realm.
Because the support and objects do not exist, the five consciousnesses also do not exist. Therefore, only the last three are bound to the formless realm.
We have explained the bound and unbound. Among the eighteen elements, how many are impure and how many are pure?
The verse says:
The mind, dharmas, and mind consciousness are both, while the rest are only impure.
The treatise says:
The mind and mind consciousness included in the truth of the path are called pure, the rest are called impure.
The dharma element, if it is the truth of the path or unconditioned, is called pure, the rest are called impure.
The remaining fifteen elements are only called impure.
Thus we have explained the impure and pure.

Among the eighteen elements, how many are with initial and sustained thought, how many are without initial thought but only with sustained thought, and how many are without either initial or sustained thought?
The verse says:
The five consciousnesses are only with initial and sustained thought. The last three are of three kinds. The rest are without.
The treatise says:

The five consciousnesses, such as visual consciousness, are with initial and sustained thought, because they are always associated with initial and sustained thought. This is because they manifest coarse characteristics and evolve externally. In order to clarify the meaning definitively, the word only is used.
The last three are the mental faculty, dharmas, and mental consciousness, because they are last among the faculties, objects, and consciousnesses.
These last three elements are all of three kinds. The mental faculty element, mental consciousness element, and the dharma element that is associated, excluding initial and sustained thought,

are with initial and sustained thought in the desire realm and first trance state. In the intermediate trance state, they are without initial thought but only with sustained thought. In the second trance state and above, up to the peak of existence, they are without either initial or sustained thought.
The dharmas included in the dharma element that are not associated, and sustained thought in the intermediate trance state, are also like this.
When it is said that there is no initial thought at all times, this means that there is no second moment of initial thought, because it is associated only with investigation.
Investigation in the realm of desire and the first trance state is not included in the three categories. What should it be called?
It should be called that which is without investigation but with only initial thought, because there is no second moment of investigation, and it is associated only with initial thought.
For this reason, it is said that the stage with both initial thought and investigation has four kinds of dharmas:
1) that which has both initial thought and investigation, that is, associated dharmas other than initial thought and investigation.
2) that which is without initial thought but only with investigation, that is, initial thought itself.
3) that which is without either initial thought or investigation, that is, all dharmas not associated with mind.
4) that which is without investigation but only with initial thought, that is, investigation itself.
The remaining ten material elements are always without either initial thought or investigation, because they are never associated with initial thought or investigation.
If the five material consciousnesses have initial thought and investigation, how can it be said that they are without discrimination?
The verse says:
It is said that the five are without discrimination, because of calculation and memory.
With scattered wisdom of the mental ground, mental various recollections as its essence.
The treatise says:
It is said that there are three kinds of discrimination:
1. Natural discrimination, 2. Conceptual discrimination, 3. Recollection discrimination.
Although the five consciousness groups have natural discrimination, they lack the other two, so it is said they are without discrimination, like a horse with one foot is called footless.
Natural discrimination is solely discursive thought. It will be explained later in the chapter on mental factors.
The other two discriminations are, in order,
scattered wisdom of the mental ground, and various recollections as their essence. Scattered means not concentrated.
Scattered wisdom associated with mental consciousness is called conceptual discrimination.
Recollection associated with either concentrated or scattered mental consciousness is called recollection discrimination.
Thus far, with discursive thought and investigation, etc., has been explained.
Among the eighteen elements, how many have objects and how many are without objects?
How many are with appropriation and how many are without appropriation?
In verse it is said:
The seven consciousnesses, half of the dharma realm, have objects, the rest do not.
The first eight realms and sound are not grasped, the other two are both.
The treatise says:
The six consciousnesses, the mind realm, and the mental factors included in the dharma realm are called having objects, because they can grasp objects.
The remaining ten form realms and the dissociated factors included in the dharma realm are called without objects, because the meaning is established by implication.
Thus far, having objects, etc. has been explained.
Among the eighteen realms, nine are not grasped: the first seven consciousness realms and the entire dharma realm. These eight and sound are all not grasped.
The remaining nine realms are both kinds: grasped and not grasped.
The five sense faculties such as the eyes, abiding in the present world, are called grasped; past and future are called not grasped.

Form, smell, taste, and touch, abiding in the present world and not separated from the five faculties, are called grasped; if abiding in the present but separated from the faculties, or past and future, they are called not grasped.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

In the body, it excludes that which is conjoined with the faculties, such as hair, body hair, nails, teeth, feces, urine, snot, spittle, blood, etc., and in the external world, it excludes earth, water, etc., and their form, smell, taste, and touch. Although they exist in the present, they are not grasped.
What is the meaning of the phrase that which is grasped?
The mind and mental factors grasp and hold it together, taking it as their basis, and it is called that which is grasped. This is because they mutually benefit each other.
In the world, it is said that there is a sense of touch, because when touched by various conditions, one experiences pleasure, etc.
That which is contrary to this is called ungrasped.
Thus far, we have discussed that which is grasped, etc.
Among the eighteen elements, how many have the nature of the great elements, and how many have the nature of the derivatives?
How many are accumulable, and how many are not accumulable?
A verse says:
In the element of touch, there are two kinds. The remaining nine forms are derivatives.
One part of the element of dharmas is also like this. Ten forms are accumulable.
The treatise says:
The element of touch is of two kinds: the great elements and their derivatives.
The four great elements are earth, fire, wind, and water.
The seven derivative elements are smoothness, roughness, lightness, heaviness, cold, hunger, and thirst. They are called derivative because they arise in dependence on the great elements.
The remaining nine material elements are only derivative, namely, the five material faculties and the four objects of form, sound, etc.
A part of the element of dharmas, namely, the form of non-information, is also only derivative.
The remaining seven elements of consciousness and a part of the element of dharmas, excluding the form of non-information, are neither of the two kinds.
The Venerable Bodhi says:
The ten kinds of material sense bases are only the four great elements.
This is not so, because a scripture says that the characteristics of hardness, etc., are the four great elements.

Because these four great elements are only included in the category of tangibility, they are not perceived by the eye, etc., as are solidity, humidity, etc. They are not perceived by the body sense-faculty as are form, sound, etc. Therefore his theory is definitely unreasonable.
Also, a scripture says:

Bhiká¹£us, you should know that the eye is an internal sense base, is composed of the four great elements, is pure form, is invisible, and has resistance. The same is true of the sense bases of the body, etc.
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that form is an external sense base, created by the four great elements, having form, visible, and resistant.
Sound is an external sense base, created by the four great elements, having form, invisible, and resistant.
The two sense bases of smell and taste are explained in the same way.
Touch is an external sense base, the four great elements and what is created by the four great elements, having form, invisible, and resistant.
In this way, the sÅ«tra only says that the sense base of touch includes the four great elements. It clearly shows that the other sense bases having form are not the great elements.
If this is so, why does the sÅ«tra say that in the flesh of the eye, internally each separately, there is solidity, the nature of solidity, and so on?
It says that apart from the flesh of the eye sense base there is the nature of solidity, etc., without contradicting the above explanation.

The SÅ«tra on Entering the Womb only says that the six elements are a person in order to show what is essential to being a person. It is not only that. That sÅ«tra also says that there are six sense bases of contact.

Also, mental activities would not exist, and you should not maintain that mental activities are mind, because a scripture says that mental activities such as conceptualization and feeling are supported by mind.
Also, it says that there is a mind with craving.
Therefore, as explained above, the distinctions among the various realms, the great elements, and the secondary characteristics are established.
This concludes the discussion of the natures of the great elements, etc.
Among the eighteen elements, the five sense organs and the five corresponding objects, for a total of ten elements with form, are aggregations, because they are aggregations of atoms.
The remaining eight elements are not aggregations, because they are not atoms.
This concludes the discussion of aggregations, etc.
Among the eighteen elements, how many can cut and how many can be cut?
How many can burn and how many can be burned?
How many can weigh and how many can be weighed?
A verse says:
Only the first four external elements can cut and be cut,
Can burn and be weighed, but there is dispute over burning.
The treatise says:
Color, smell, taste, and touch constitute the axe and firewood, etc., and this is called that which cuts and that which is cut.
What dharma is called cutting?
When a mass of color such as firewood is born in continuous contact, the axe, etc., divides it and causes it to arise separately. This dharma is called cutting.
The physical sense organs, etc., are not called that which is cut, because they cannot be completely severed to form two parts.
The sense organs such as the body cannot be divided into two parts, because when the limbs are separated from the body, they are no longer sense organs.
Moreover, the sense organs such as the body are also not that which cuts, because they are pure and subtle, like the light of a precious jewel.

Just as the essence of that which cuts and that which is cut consists only of the four external elements, the essence of that which is burned and that which weighs is also the same, namely, only the four external elements are called that which is burned and that which weighs.
The physical sense organs are also not the two things, because they are pure and subtle, like the light of a precious jewel.
The sound element is generally not [that which is burned or weighed], because it does not continue in a series.
There is a dispute over that which burns and that which weighs. Some say:
The essence of that which burns and that which weighs is also as before, consisting only of the four external elements.
Some say:
Only the fire element can be called that which burns, and that which is weighed is only heavy.
Thus, that which is cut, etc. has been explained.
Among the eighteen elements, how many are born of retribution, how many are nourished, how many are of the nature of outflow, how many are real entities, and how many are momentary?
Verse:
The first five have retribution and nourishment. Sound is not born of retribution.
Eight are without obstruction and outflow, and also of the nature of retribution.
The other three are real entities, and only the last three are momentary.
Commentary:
The first five are the five elements of the eye, etc.
They are born of retribution, nourished, and without outflow. Apart from being born of retribution and nourished, there is no separate nature.
That which is produced by the cause of retribution is called born of retribution, like a cart drawn by an ox is called an ox cart, omitting the middle phrase, therefore it is said.
Or, the action that is done matures and is able to ripen when it reaches the time of receiving its fruit, and for that reason it is called retribution.
The fruit that arises from it is called retribution.
The fruit that it receives is a different species from its cause, and it is what is ripened, and for that reason it is called retribution.
Or, the name of the fruit is metaphorically established on the basis of the cause, just as the name of the cause is metaphorically established on the basis of the fruit.
A scripture says,
The present six sense bases should be understood as the action done in the past.
Nourishment, sleep, and concentration are the superior conditions that benefit, and for that reason they are called nourishment.
Some say that
pure conduct also nourishes.
This only means that it does not harm, not that it benefits.
It always protects and sustains the continuity of retribution, just as outer fortifications protect a city.
Sound is of the class of the born of retribution and of the class of nourishment. It is not born of retribution.
Why is this?
Because it changes according to ones wishes.
If this is so, then why does the AbhidharmasÄra say, â€œAs a result of cultivating the avoidance of coarse speech, one obtains the mark of a great man of the BrahmÄâ€™s soundâ€?
Some say:
Because sound is the third derivative of the primary elements, it is not a ripening even though it arises from action.
That is, the primary elements from which it arises are born from action. The primary elements are struck and emit sound.
Some say:
Because sound is the fifth derivative of the primary elements, it is not a ripening even though it arises from action.
That is, the primary elements that are born from action are derivative elements of nourishment. These in turn produce derivative elements of the same species, which then produce sound.
If this is so, then bodily sensation must not be a ripening, because it is born from the primary elements produced by action.
If sensation is like sound, then it contradicts correct reasoning.
The eight unimpeded faculties are the seven mind and dharma faculties. They are of the nature of both the same species as cause and as result and also of the nature of ripening.

That which is produced by similar and universal causes is of the nature of outflow. If it is attracted by the cause of retribution, it is called born of retribution. The unobstructed dharmas are not increased by nourishment because they are not accumulated.
The remaining four are the remaining four:
form, smell, taste, and touch. All are of three kinds: there is that born of retribution, there is that nourished, and there is that of the nature of outflow.
The real is only the dharma realm. The real refers to the unconditioned because it is solid and real.
This is categorized as the dharma realm, and therefore only the dharma realm is said to be real.
The mind, dharmas, and mental consciousness are called the last three because they are mentioned last in the six sets of three.

Only these three realms have one moment, that is, the class of receptivity to the knowledge of the dharma of suffering that is pure for the first time, because it is not outflow and is called one moment.
This refers to the ultimate, which is not outflow. The remaining conditioned dharmas are all outflow.

The mind associated with receptivity to the knowledge of the dharma of suffering is called the mind realm and the mental consciousness realm. The remaining dharmas that occur together are called the dharma realm.
Thus we have explained the nature of the various types of form.
Now we should consider whether if one obtains the eye element that was not previously obtained, one also obtains eye consciousness.
If one obtains eye consciousness that was not previously obtained, does one also obtain the eye element?
We should briefly answer these and other questions.
The verse states:
The eye and eye consciousness element are obtained alone or together, but not equally.
The commentary states:

Obtained alone means that there may be the eye element that was not previously obtained but is now obtained, but not eye consciousness. This refers to gradually obtaining the eye faculty in the desire realm, and when dying in the formless realm and being reborn in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions.

There may be eye consciousness that was not previously obtained but is now obtained, but not the eye element. This refers to the manifestation of eye consciousness in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions, and when dying in those realms and being reborn in lower realms.

Obtained together means that there may be the two elements that were not previously obtained but are now obtained. This refers to when dying in the formless realm and being reborn in the desire realm or the Brahma world.
The non-associated are those that are neither, namely, excluding the above characteristics.
Equal means: if one possesses the eye element, does one also possess eye consciousness?
One should make four alternatives.
The first alternative is: one born in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions, whose eye consciousness does not arise.
The second alternative is: one born in the desire realm who has not yet obtained the eye faculty, or who has obtained it but has lost it.

The third alternative is: one born in the desire realm who has obtained the eye faculty and has not lost it, or one born in the Brahma world or in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions, when one is correctly seeing forms.
The fourth alternative is: excluding the above characteristics.
In this way, the eye element and the form element,

the eye consciousness and the form element, should be considered in terms of attainment, etc., as appropriate. In order to include these previously unmentioned meanings, the verse summarizes and repeats etc.
Thus, attainment, etc. have been explained.
Among the eighteen elements, how many are internal and how many are external?
A verse says:
The twelve internal ones are the eye, etc., the six forms, etc. are external.
The treatise says:
The six sense organs and the six consciousnesses are called the twelve internal bases. The remaining six sense objects are called the external bases.
The self is said to be internal, and what is other than that is external.
Since the self does not exist, how can there be internal and external?
Because it is the support of the attachment to self, the mind is metaphorically referred to as the self.
Therefore a scripture says:
Because the self is well subdued, the wise one attains birth in heaven.
The World-Honored One said in other places that the mind is to be subdued. A scripture says:
One should well subdue the mind, for the subdued mind leads to happiness.
Therefore the self is only a metaphor for the mind.
The eye, etc., are called internal because they are the proximate support of the mind.
Form, etc., are called external because they are the remote objects of the mind.
If this is so, then the six consciousnesses should not be called internal, because prior to becoming mental consciousnesses, they are not supports of mind.

When they become mental consciousnesses, they do not lose the nature of the six consciousnesses, and when they are not yet mental consciousnesses, they do not exceed the characteristics of mental consciousness.

If it were otherwise, the realm of thought would exist only in the past, and the six consciousnesses would exist only in the present and future, and this would contradict the accepted doctrine that the eighteen realms are found in all three times.

Also, if the six consciousnesses of the future and present do not have the characteristics of the realm of thought, then the realm of thought in the past should not be established, because its characteristics would not change in the three times.
The internal and external have been discussed.
How many of the eighteen realms are similar and how many are dissimilar?
The verse states:
The dharma realm is similar, the other two are both active and inactive in their own activity.
The treatise states:
The similar dharma realm refers to the single dharma realm that is only similar.
If an object definitely becomes the object of a consciousness, and the consciousness has already arisen or will arise with regard to it, this object is said to be similar.

There is not a single dharma realm in which limitless mental consciousnesses have not already arisen, are not presently arising, or will not arise, because all sages definitely give rise to the mind that contemplates all dharmas as being without self.
Except for its own substance and dharmas that coexist with it, all other dharmas are its objects.

The objects excluded in this way are also the objects of the second moment of mind. These two moments of mind pervade all objects without exception. Therefore, the dharma realm is always called homogeneous.
The other two means the remaining seventeen sense bases are both homogeneous and heterogeneous.
What are called homogeneous and heterogeneous?
It means performing one's own function and not performing one's own function.
If one performs one's own function, it is called homogeneous. If one does not perform one's own function, it is called heterogeneous.

Here, the eye sense base, with regard to visible forms that have been seen, are being seen, or will be seen, is called homogeneous eye. This is explained extensively up to the mind sense base, each of which should be explained in terms of their own objects and functions.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas of KaÅ›mÄ«ra say:
The heterogeneous eye only has four kinds: that which does not see form, has already ceased, is just ceasing, or is not subject to arising.
The Western masters say there are five kinds:
That is, dharmas that do not arise are divided into two kinds: those associated with consciousness and those not associated with consciousness. The same is true of the body element.
The similar and dissimilar classes of mind are only dharmas that do not arise.

Visible form that is seen, is being seen, or will be seen by the eye is called the similar class of form. The dissimilar class of form is also of four kinds: that which is not seen by the eye, is now perishing, has already perished, or is a dharma that does not arise. The same is true of the elements of the other sense organs up to the tangible.
Each should be discussed in terms of its own function in relation to its own organ. You should understand that the similar and dissimilar classes are the same.
If the eye is the similar class for one person, it is also the similar class for all others.
The dissimilar class is also like this. The same is true of the mind element.
Visible form is not the same. For the one who sees it, it is the similar class; for the one who does not see it, it is the dissimilar class.
Why is this?
Because it is possible for one visible form to be seen by many people, such as when they observe the moon, a dance, or a wrestling match.
The eye does not have this, that is, one eye faculty can see two colors, because the eye is not shared. Based on a single continuity, it establishes the similar and dissimilar.
Because form is shared, it establishes the similar and dissimilar based on many continuities.
As explained for the form realm, sound, smell, taste, and touch should be understood in the same way.
Sound can be like form.
The three of smell, taste, and touch are taken only when they reach the faculty, because they are not shared. One takes them, not the other.
Reason should be like the eye, etc., and should not be explained like form.
Although there is this principle, it may be shared.
Why is this?

Among the eighteen realms, how many are views and how many are not views?
The verse states:
Eight kinds, such as the eye and part of the dharma realm, are called views.

The entire eye is a view. Part of the dharma realm, which is of eight kinds, is a view. The rest are not views.

Just as in the night and day periods, with and without clouds, the images of many colors are seen with different degrees of clarity, so it is with the various views of the world, with and without contamination.
The views of those still learning and those no longer learning observe the characteristics of dharmas with different degrees of clarity.
Why is this?

Correct views of the world are only associated with mental consciousness, because the wisdom born with the five consciousnesses cannot make decisions. Prior to careful consideration, decisions are called views.
The wisdom born with the five consciousnesses does not have this ability, and therefore it is not view, because it is without discrimination.

Because it is said that the eye sees visible form and distinguishes visible form, just as a small part of discernment is called seeing and also is able to discriminate.

The great masters of Abhidharma all say:

If this school says that the eye sees, the ear hears, and so on up to the mental faculty cognizes, when the sense faculty is actually perceiving the object it takes, is it to or not to reach it?
